thread.title: Fish fingers and Walkers crisps are set for price hike due to Brexit effect
thread.title_full: Fish fingers and Walkers crisps are set for price hike due to Brexit effect

author: Cheyenne Roundtree
title: Fish fingers and Walkers crisps are set for price hike due to Brexit effect
text:
Fish fingers and Walkers crisps are set for price hike due to Brexit effect Birds Eye is considering raising prices of products by 12% or decreasing the size of packages Share A pack of Birds Eye Fish Fingers Share Get what's on   
Fish fingers and Walkers crisps could see a major price hike after companies ask supermarkets to raise prices due to the diminishing value of the pound. 
Since the Brexit vote in June , the pound’s value has decreased by around 17 percent and food companies are looking to stabilize their profits by enacting price hikes. 
Birds Eye, supplier of popular items such as fish fingers, peas, chicken nuggets, waffles and ready-made meals, is considering a 12% rise in prices of some of its products next month. 
Another option the company might implement is decreasing the size of packages, meaning less food for the same price. Walkers want to raise the price of a bag of their crisps from 50p to 55p in the wake of Brexit (Photo: Simon Cooper/PA Wire) 
Walkers is another prominent company that is considering making its products more expensive due to the weakened pound. 
Owned by US company PepsiCo, Walkers wants to make a standard bag of crisps from 55p, instead of its current 50p price tag, the Guardian reports. 
Birds Eye and Walkers are just some of the latest companies to follow in the footsteps of Unilever, the owners of Marmite, that pulled its products off of Tesco’s online shelves temporarily after a pricing disagreement in October. Read More Missing Marmite and bye bye Ben & Jerry's: Is Brexit hitting our supermarket shelves? 
Other items to disappear or failed to be restocked besides Marmite in the row, were Ben & Jerry’s, Cornetto, Pot Noodle, PG Tips and Walls. 
Although it is up to the supermarkets if they chose to decide if they allow the price hike, some stores are folding to demands and raising prices. Morrisons has jacked up the price of Marmite by 12.5% (Photo: Chris Radburn/PA Wire) 
Morrisons increased the price of Marmite by 12.5% after witnessing Unilever’s fallout with Tesco. 
Wayne Hudson, managing director of Birds Eye in the UK and Ireland, told Wales Online: “Many of our raw materials are priced in dollars, and the fall in the value of the pound since the EU referendum has meant that our costs in sterling have risen. Our first priority is always to the people who buy our brands, and we are working to absorb these costs as much as possible.” Share
